elements.content: To systematically investigate the factors that influence the formation of various metal(II) complexes, dual systems containing a flexible benzene dicarboxylate and two kinds of dipyridyl-type coligands are assembled into six metal(II) complexes, formulated as {[Zn(phda)(bpa)]·(H2O)3} n (1), {[Zn2(phda)2(dpe)2]·(H2O)} n (2), [Co(phda)(bpa)(H2O] n (3), [Co(phda)(dpe)] n (4), [Mn(phda)(bpa)(H2O)] n (5), and [Mn(phda)(dpe)0.5(H2O)] n (6) (phda = 1,2-phenylenediacetate, dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene, and bpa = 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane). The X-ray single crystal diffractions show that the formed six complexes reveal a diversified structure topology under the regulation of two kinds of dipyridyl-type coligands and are further divided into three complex pairs based on the nature of metal cations. Each pair of complexes is assembled from the same metal cation and different dipyridyl-type coligands to produce disparate structures respectively: the three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic frameworks of zinc complex pairs (1, 2) feature a single dia net with permanent porosity when the free solvent molecules are evacuated and a 4-fold interpenetrated dia net with dense structure, respectively; cobalt complexes pairs (3, 4) exhibit a two-dimensional (4,4) grid and a 3D self-penetrated framework with (48668) rob net, respectively. Both manganese complex pairs (5, 6) display (4,4) grids except that the former contains linear metal carboxylates and the latter consists of ribbonlike metal carboxylates. In addition, thermal stability of complex 1, luminescent properties of the zinc complex pairs (1, 2), and magnetic properties of complexes 4 and 6 are also systematically investigated.

elements.content: The reactions of metal(II) and the flexible 1,2-phenylenediacetate assemble into three coupled complexes under the control of two kinds of dipyridyl-type coligands: the coupled zinc complexes feature a dia net with superior cavities and the 4-fold interpenetrated net, the coupled cobalt complexes display the (4,4) grid and the self-penetrated rob net, and two manganese complexes possess different (4,4) grids.

elements.content: In the last two decades, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with well-regulated network structures have provoked significant interest as functional materials displaying potential applications in such fields as magnetism, molecular separation, catalysis, luminescence, and molecule storage. The well-designed synthesis of MOFs can be rationalized by the shrewd choice of functional organic ligands. The role of the organic linkers can be explained in terms of their differences in the size, the flexibility, the coordination ability, the number of the carboxylate groups, the positions of the carboxylate groups, the nature of the substituting groups, and coordination modes to various metal ions. Simultaneously, neutral dipyridyl-type molecules can pillar dicarboxylate motifs into higher dimensionality, appreciably altering the overall structural topology.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the last two decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with well-regulated network structures have provoked significant interest as functional materials displaying potential applications in such fields as magnetism, molecular separation, catalysis, luminescence, and molecule storage. The well-designed synthesis of MOFs can be rationalized by the shrewd choice of functional organic ligands. The role of the organic linkers can be explained in terms of their differences in the size, the flexibility, the coordination ability, the number of the carboxylate groups, the positions of the carboxylate groups, the nature of the substituting groups, and coordination modes to various metal ions. Simultaneously, neutral dipyridyl-type molecules can pillar dicarboxylate motifs into higher dimensionality, appreciably altering the overall structural topology.

elements.content: It is to be noted that the flexibility of the ligand can afford a good opportunity to enrich the structural and functional diversities of MOFs, which maybe provides further understanding of the directional synthesis of target complexes. So far, flexible ligands have been used widely in the construction of MOFs with interesting topologies and attractive properties. These ligands are of interest based on the following reasons: (a) the facile twisted conformations can lead to versatile topologies such as cages, honeycombs, interpenetrating networks, and helical structures; (b) the flexible ligand is apt to display variable coordination modes resulting from the geometry restrictions imposed by the coordination of the center metal cation; (c) larger molecular size for this primary building unit may provide more opportunities for the formation of microporous frameworks. Benzene multicarboxylate ligands are among the most commonly employed linkers in MOFs chemistry. Subsequently, a new family of benzene multicarboxylates with long-spanning carboxyl groups has been used by us and others, making some fascinating structures including helices and interpenetrating networks that may be attributed to the flexibility of carboxyl groups. More recently, a well-defined synthetic system containing various divalent metal acetates, 1,2-phenylenediacetate (H2phda), and 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane coligand is systematically investigated by us. The preliminary work shows that the structure and dimensionality of formed MOFs are highly sensitive to the nature of metal cations.

Benzene multicarboxylate ligands are among the most commonly employed linkers in MOFs chemistry. Subsequently, a new family of benzene multicarboxylates with long-spanning carboxyl groups has been used by us and others, making some fascinating structures including helices and interpenetrating networks that may be attributed to the flexibility of carboxyl groups. elements.content: To extend our previous work, we have endeavored to further investigate the effect of N-donor ligands on the framework topology of MOFs in this synthesis system. A series of coordination polymers assembled by the flexible H2phda and two types of N-donor ligands, that is, 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpa) and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe), were isolated under similar hydrothermal conditions (Scheme ). Herein, the structures and topologies of these compounds along with the influence of synthetic parameters on the structures are presented in detail. Furthermore, thermal stability of complex 1, the fluorescence properties of both zinc complexes, and magnetic properties of complexes 4 and 6 are given.

elements.content: All reagents used in these syntheses were of analytical grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a VECTOR-22 spectrophotometer within 400–4000 cm–1 using the samples prepared as pellets with KBr. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer. Luminescence spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured by using a MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants for all constituent atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents used in these syntheses were of analytical grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a VECTOR-22 spectrophotometer within 400-4000 cm-1 using the samples prepared as pellets with KBr. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer. Luminescence spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured by using a MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants for all constituent atoms.

elements.content: The mixtures of H2phda (0.1 mmol, 19.4 mg), bpa (0.2 mmol, 39.7 mg), Zn(OAC)2·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 22.0 mg), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 2.0 mL), and H2O (6.0 mL) were placed in a 23 mL Teflon liner stainless steel reactor. The vessel was heated to 120 °C for 4 days, and then cooled at 5 °C h–1 to room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained, and further crystals were filtered off, washed with mother liquid, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield 53%. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C22H26N2O7Zn: C 53.29, H 5.29, N 5.65 Found: C 53.27, H 4.82, N 5.26. Select IR (cm–1): 3320m, 1598s, 1492m, 1402m, 1356s, 1220w, 1206m, 1120m, 998m, 802s, 685s.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1–6 were mounted on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.071073 nm) by using Φ/ω scan technique at room temperature. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structures were solved using direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model except for those bound to water molecules, which were initially located in a difference Fourier map and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restraints with the O–H distances being fixed at 0.85 Å and U iso(H) equivalent to 1.5 times of U eq(O). All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-97 program package. Crystal data and experimental details for compounds 1–6 are contained in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1-6 were mounted on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.071073 nm) by using Φ/ω scan technique at room temperature. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structures were solved using direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model except for those bound to water molecules, which were initially located in a difference Fourier map and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restraints with the O-H distances being fixed at 0.85 Å and U iso(H) equivalent to 1.5 times of U eq(O). All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-97 program package. Crystal data and experimental details for compounds 1-6 are contained in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in .

Hydrothermal method has been proven to be a powerful approach for the preparation of sparingly soluble organic–inorganic hybrid materials. However, the given crystal growth is influenced by various hydrothermal parameters such as the pH value, temperature, the molar ratio of the reactant and reactant solvent, etc. The syntheses for complexes 1–6 are mainly dominated by two synthetic parameters, i.e., reactant solvent and pH value. When the syntheses are manipulated in the pure water solvent, the reactions of metal(II) acetate (metal = Zn, Co, or Mn) with H2phda and dipyridyl-type molecule only give powder samples or very small polycrystals, whereas the ideal single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis can be isolated in the reaction medium of DMF and H2O mixture (V DMF/V H2O = 1: 3), which indicates that the DMF solvent may be in favor of the crystallizations of all these complexes. In addition, a relatively higher pH value is necessary for the formations of both cobalt complexes (3, 4). When the syntheses for two cobalt complexes are manipulated at pH < 6, only unknown powder samples are formed. However, the ideal crystals suitable for the X-ray single diffraction analysis can be obtained in a pH range of 6–8, which means that the assembly of two compounds is highly sensitive to the pH values of the reaction systems. Furthermore, all the carboxylate groups of the H2phda in these six complexes are found to be completely deprotonated as evidenced by the results of structure analyses and IR with the absence of the expected absorption band in the range of 1760–1680 cm–1 for the protonated carboxylate groups. Various coordination modes of phda anion observed in complexes 1–6 are shown in Scheme , and the further structural details for the related complexes are described below.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Hydrothermal method has been proven to be a powerful approach for the preparation of sparingly soluble organic-inorganic hybrid materials. However, the given crystal growth is influenced by various hydrothermal parameters such as the pH value, temperature, the molar ratio of the reactant and reactant solvent, etc. The syntheses for complexes 1-6 are mainly dominated by two synthetic parameters, i.e., reactant solvent and pH value. When the syntheses are manipulated in the pure water solvent, the reactions of metal(II) acetate (metal = Zn, Co, or Mn) with H2phda and dipyridyl-type molecule only give powder samples or very small polycrystals, whereas the ideal single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis can be isolated in the reaction medium of DMF and H2O mixture (V DMF/V H2O = 1: 3), which indicates that the DMF solvent may be in favor of the crystallizations of all these complexes. In addition, a relatively higher pH value is necessary for the formations of both cobalt complexes (3, 4). When the syntheses for two cobalt complexes are manipulated at pH < 6, only unknown powder samples are formed. However, the ideal crystals suitable for the X-ray single diffraction analysis can be obtained in a pH range of 6-8, which means that the assembly of two compounds is highly sensitive to the pH values of the reaction systems. Furthermore, all the carboxylate groups of the H2phda in these six complexes are found to be completely deprotonated as evidenced by the results of structure analyses and IR with the absence of the expected absorption band in the range of 1760-1680 cm-1 for the protonated carboxylate groups. Various coordination modes of phda anion observed in complexes 1-6 are shown in Scheme , and the further structural details for the related complexes are described below.

elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination Modes of H2phda Observed in Complexes 1-6

elements.content: Complex 1 displays a porous metal–organic framework with 66- dia topology. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) ion, one phda dianion, two one-half bpa molecules in special positions, and three guest water molecules. As shown in Figure a, the Zn(II) ion is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two symmetry-related bpa ligands (Zn(1)–N(1) = 2.042(5) and Zn(1)–N(2) = 2.059(5) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two symmetry-related phda anions (Zn(1)–O(3)#1 = 1.928(4) and Zn(1)–O(1) = 1.969(4) Å). Each phda anion through a bis(monodentate) coordinated mode bridges the adjacent Zn(II) atoms (Scheme a) to yield a undulating [Zn(phda)] n chain () with a through-ligand Zn···Zn contact distance of 8.9610 Å, which is further cross-linked by bpa coligands along two different directions to develop a 3D porous framework (Figure b). From a topological perspective, compound 1 can be described as a 4-connected net with 66 - dia topology (Figure c). Each metal center node is linked to four neighbors, forming six 6-membered circuits at each metal atom.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions

{[Zn(phda)(bpa)]⋅(H2O)3} n  (1)

Complex 1 displays a porous metal-organic framework with 66- dia  topology. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) ion, one phda dianion, two one-half bpa molecules in special positions, and three guest water molecules. As shown in Figure a, the Zn(II) ion is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two symmetry-related bpa ligands (Zn(1)-N(1) = 2.042(5) and Zn(1)-N(2) = 2.059(5) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two symmetry-related phda anions (Zn(1)-O(3)#1 = 1.928(4) and Zn(1)-O(1) = 1.969(4) Å). Each phda anion through a bis(monodentate) coordinated mode bridges the adjacent Zn(II) atoms (Scheme a) to yield a undulating [Zn(phda)] n  chain () with a through-ligand Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn contact distance of 8.9610 Å, which is further cross-linked by bpa coligands along two different directions to develop a 3D porous framework (Figure b). From a topological perspective, compound 1 can be described as a 4-connected net with 66 -  dia  topology (Figure c). Each metal center node is linked to four neighbors, forming six 6-membered circuits at each metal atom.

elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn(II) ion in 1. Symmetry codes: A = 1.5 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; B = 3 – x, 1 – y, –z; C = 3 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z. (b) A polyhedral view of the 3D open-porous structure. (c) Schematic representation of 66- dia topology for 1. (d) The 3D open framework filled by guest H2O molecules. (e) A water chain formed by H-bonding interactions.

(b) A polyhedral view of the 3D open-porous structure. (c) Schematic representation of 66- dia  topology for 1. (d) The 3D open framework filled by guest H2O molecules. (e) A water chain formed by H-bonding interactions.

elements.content: Interestingly, the 3D open framework with channels of 9.30 × 9.31 Å2 along the b axis and of 7.6 × 9.31 Å2 along the a axis, which are occupied by free water molecules (Figure d), cohered together by hydrogen-bonding interactions to form the water tapes (Figure e). Among them, all water molecules act as both donors and acceptors (), and two kinds of H-bonds exist (): (1) the oxygen in one water as donors and the hydrogen in two adjacent water molecules as acceptor (Ow···Ow distances are 2.805–2.863 Å), which favors the formation of water chain; (2) the carboxylate oxygen in the framework as donors and the hydrogen atoms in the guest water as acceptor (Ocarboxylate···Ow distances are 2.774–2.947 Å), which favors the stability of the water chain. Furthermore, a wide range of 145.2–179.7° for the O–H···O angles provides flexibility to the water molecules in this environment so that they can be accommodated in the channels with the aid of hydrogen bonding to the oxygen atoms of the framework and can maximize the interactions among themselves, thereby stabilizing water molecules in channels. Water clusters have attracted considerable attention both theoretically and experimentally, since they play a crucial role in contributing to the stability and function of biological assemblies.

elements.content: Complex 2 features a 4-fold interpenetrated metal–organic framework based on 66- dia net. The asymmetric unit contains two divalent Zn atoms on crystallographic inversion centers, two phda dianions, two dpe molecules, and one guest water molecule (Figure a). All the Zn cations are four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two bpa ligands and two oxygen atoms from two phda anions. The Zn–O and Zn–N bond lengths and related angles for Zn1O2N2 and Zn2O2N2 tetrahedra are slightly different (). Among them, the Zn1–N bond lengths are 2.041(3) and 2.103(3) Å, and the Zn1–O bond lengths are 1.911(3) and 1.971(3) Å. However, the Zn2–N bond lengths are 2.047(3) and 2.064(3) Å, and the Zn2–O bond lengths are 1.925(3) and 1.926(3) Å.

Complex 2 features a 4-fold interpenetrated metal-organic framework based on 66- dia  net. The asymmetric unit contains two divalent Zn atoms on crystallographic inversion centers, two phda dianions, two dpe molecules, and one guest water molecule (Figure a). All the Zn cations are four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two bpa ligands and two oxygen atoms from two phda anions. The Zn-O and Zn-N bond lengths and related angles for Zn1O2N2 and Zn2O2N2 tetrahedra are slightly different (). Among them, the Zn1-N bond lengths are 2.041(3) and 2.103(3) Å, and the Zn1-O bond lengths are 1.911(3) and 1.971(3) Å. However, the Zn2-N bond lengths are 2.047(3) and 2.064(3) Å, and the Zn2-O bond lengths are 1.925(3) and 1.926(3) Å.

elements.content: Each phda anion through a bis(monodentate) coordinated mode connects the adjacent Zn(II) atoms (Scheme a) to form [Zn(phda)] n chains (), which are further connected by dpe molecules extending into a 3D net with 66 - dia topology similar to that in complex 1 (). Although each 66- dia net also has large channels permitted by the 13.48 × 13.42 Å apertures as measured by through-space Zn···Zn distances (Figure b), they are mainly filled by the three other equivalent nets to form a 3D → 3D 4-fold interpenetrated framework (Figure c). Furthermore, the extra-framework interspaces decrease tremendously due to the interpenetrated arrangement of four 66 - dia nets, and thus fewer solvent molecules exist in this structure compared to complex 1. Intermolecular forces encourage the interpenetration of coordination networks because the crystallized waters enable hydrogen bonds between independent nets (Ocarboxylate···Ow distances are 2.825(5)–2.836(6) Å); the detailed hydrogen bonds are found in .

Although each 66- dia  net also has large channels permitted by the 13.48 × 13.42 Å apertures as measured by through-space Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances (Figure b), they are mainly filled by the three other equivalent nets to form a 3D → 3D 4-fold interpenetrated framework (Figure c). elements.content: Notably, the hydrothermal reactions of Zn(II) with carboxylate are apt to lead to the formation of interpenetrated diamondoid nets, and odd-numbered levels of interpenetration in diamondoid coordination polymer lattices tend to result in acentricity, while even-numbered interpenetration levels promote the presence of crystallographic inversion centers. However, compound 2 belongs to the acentric nature with Pc space group, which stands on opposite sides of this previous trend. It is probably attributed to the flexibility of the twisted arms of the phda dianion promoting the loss of inversion centers.

However, compound 2 belongs to the acentric nature with Pc space group, which stands on opposite sides of this previous trend. elements.content: Complex 3 exhibits a 2D layer containing phda-bridged mononuclear cobalt. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) cation, one phda anion, one bpa molecule, and one coordinated water molecule, as shown in Figure a. Each Co atom is octahedrally coordinated by three carboxylate O donors of two symmetry-related phda anions and one coordinated water molecule in the equatorial plane with two N donors of two symmetry-related bpa ligands in the axial positions. The Co–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.0611(12)–2.2320(13) Å, and the Co–N bond lengths are 2.1510(14) and 2.1792(14) Å, respectively.

[Co(phda)(bpa)(H2O] n  (3)

Complex 3 exhibits a 2D layer containing phda-bridged mononuclear cobalt. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) cation, one phda anion, one bpa molecule, and one coordinated water molecule, as shown in Figure a. Each Co atom is octahedrally coordinated by three carboxylate O donors of two symmetry-related phda anions and one coordinated water molecule in the equatorial plane with two N donors of two symmetry-related bpa ligands in the axial positions. The Co-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.0611(12)-2.2320(13) Å, and the Co-N bond lengths are 2.1510(14) and 2.1792(14) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Both carboxylate groups of the phda ligand bridge the adjacent Co(II) centers by a monodentate bridging and a bidentate chelating mode (Scheme b) to form Co carboxylate linear chains running along the crystallographic a axis. The adjacent chains are further interconnected to each other through the bpa molecules resulting in (4,4) grids (Figure b) with a side length of 13.7324/8.6406 Å based on the Co···Co distances.
elements.clean_text: Both carboxylate groups of the phda ligand bridge the adjacent Co(II) centers by a monodentate bridging and a bidentate chelating mode (Scheme b) to form Co carboxylate linear chains running along the crystallographic a axis. The adjacent chains are further interconnected to each other through the bpa molecules resulting in (4,4) grids (Figure b) with a side length of 13.7324/8.6406 Å based on the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances.

elements.content: Notably, the presence of coordinated water molecules leads to the formation of extensive H-bonding interactions (Figure c). Besides intramolecular O(5W)–H(2W)···O(1) hydrogen bonds, interlayer O(5W)–H(1W)···O(4) interactions further extend the adjacent 2D layers to produce a 2D bilayer network (Figure d). The detail of the hydrogen bonds is shown in . The adjacent H-bonding 2D bilayers stack in a slightly offset parallel fashion and cohere together by the weak van der Waals force to form its entire 3D supermolecular structure.

elements.content: Complex 4 possesses a 3D self-penetrated metal–organic framework featuring Co carboxylate layers pillared by dpe molecules. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) cation, one phda ligand, and one dpe molecule, as shown in Figure a. Each Co atom is octahedrally coordinated by two N atoms of two symmetry-related dpe ligands and four oxygen atoms from three symmetry-related phda ligands. The Co–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.003(3)–2.376(4) Å and the Co–N bond lengths are 2.148(3) and 2.159(3) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
[Co(phda)(dpe)] n  (4)

Complex 4 possesses a 3D self-penetrated metal-organic framework featuring Co carboxylate layers pillared by dpe molecules. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) cation, one phda ligand, and one dpe molecule, as shown in Figure a. Each Co atom is octahedrally coordinated by two N atoms of two symmetry-related dpe ligands and four oxygen atoms from three symmetry-related phda ligands. The Co-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.003(3)-2.376(4) Å and the Co-N bond lengths are 2.148(3) and 2.159(3) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Each phda anion acts as a tetradentate ligand connecting three Co ions, one carboxylate group bidentately bridging two Co atoms and the other bidentately chelating one Co atom (Scheme c). Two Co neighbors are cohered together by a pair of the acetates from two phda anions to form Co dimers with a Co...Co distance of 4.1753(17) Å, which are further linked by four bridging phda ligands to develop a Co carboxylate layer (Figure b). Adjacent layers are pillared by dpe molecules to generate a novel 3D self-penetrating framework (Figure c).

Adjacent layers are pillared by dpe molecules to generate a novel 3D self-penetrating framework (Figure c).

elements.content: Topologically, the Co dimers can be regarded as the network nodes, each of which connects to six adjacent ones with four within the (4,4) grid layer and two from pairs of slanted dpe ligands. Thus, the 3D coordination polymer lattice for 4 can be characterized as a 6-connected self-penetrated network with (48668) rob topology (Figure d).

elements.content: Complex 5 exhibits a similar 2D configuration to complex 3 featuring phda-bridged mononuclear metal except a different coordinated mode for the phda anion and polyhedral geometry for metal cation. The asymmetric unit of compounds 5 contains one Mn cation, one phda anion, one bpa coligand, and one coordinated water molecule; all the components are located in the special positions (Figure a). The Mn cation is located in a seven-coordinated distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry with four oxygen atoms from two symmetry-related carboxylate groups (Mn–O: 2.2626(15) Å and 2.4456(16) Å), two nitrogen atoms from bpa ligands (Mn–N: 2.2959(15) Å), and one ligated water molecule (Mn–O: 2.190(2) Å).

[Mn(phda)(bpa)(H2O)] n  (5)

Complex 5 exhibits a similar 2D configuration to complex 3 featuring phda-bridged mononuclear metal except a different coordinated mode for the phda anion and polyhedral geometry for metal cation. The asymmetric unit of compounds 5 contains one Mn cation, one phda anion, one bpa coligand, and one coordinated water molecule; all the components are located in the special positions (Figure a). The Mn cation is located in a seven-coordinated distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry with four oxygen atoms from two symmetry-related carboxylate groups (Mn-O: 2.2626(15) Å and 2.4456(16) Å), two nitrogen atoms from bpa ligands (Mn-N: 2.2959(15) Å), and one ligated water molecule (Mn-O: 2.190(2) Å).

elements.content: Each phda anion acts as a tetradentate ligand with the chelating coordination mode (Scheme d), connecting the adjacent Mn(II) ions into a 1D chain along the c direction. The 1D motifs are further extended by bpa spacers to result in a 2D rhombic grid (Figure b). The H-bonding interactions within the interlayer extend the adjacent 2D layers into a 2D supramolecular bilayer (O(3W)–H(1W)···O(1)), which is also similar to compound 3 (), though no intralayer H-bonding interactions are found in this structure. The adjacent bilayer motifs are stacked in a parallel fashion and cohered together by the weak van der Waals force to form its entire 3D supramolecular network.

elements.content: Complex 6 exhibits a 2D layer containing phda-bridged binuclear manganese. The asymmetric unit consists of one Mn(II) atom, one phda anion, half a dpe coligand, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). Each Mn center has an octahedrally coordinated geometry with the basal plane occupied by four oxygen atoms from three phda ligands by mono-/bidentate alternately coordinated modes that are similar to those in 4 (Scheme c) (Mn–O bond lengths are range from 2.1202(11) Å to 2.3336(11) Å), while one bpa pyridyl N and one coordinated water molecule occupy the apical sites (Mn–N = 2.2822(12) Å and Mn–Ow = 2.1688(11) Å). The [MnO4N2] environment is best described as a slightly distorted octahedron, as is the case for 3 and 4.

Complex 6 exhibits a 2D layer containing phda-bridged binuclear manganese. The asymmetric unit consists of one Mn(II) atom, one phda anion, half a dpe coligand, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). Each Mn center has an octahedrally coordinated geometry with the basal plane occupied by four oxygen atoms from three phda ligands by mono-/bidentate alternately coordinated modes that are similar to those in 4 (Scheme c) (Mn-O bond lengths are range from 2.1202(11) Å to 2.3336(11) Å), while one bpa pyridyl N and one coordinated water molecule occupy the apical sites (Mn-N = 2.2822(12) Å and Mn-Ow = 2.1688(11) Å). elements.content: Two adjacent Mn atoms are cohered together by a pair of the acetates from two phda anions to form Mn dimers, which are bridged by the phda anions to generate a 1D ribbonlike chain (Figure b). Two carboxylate groups bridge two Mn(II) ions to form the 8-MRs, and two phda ligands bridge two Mn(II) ions to form the 18-MRs with Mn···Mn separations of 4.1315(5) and 5.5048(6) Å, respectively. The resulting chains are linked by the dpe coligands to extend into a rhombic 2D grid with a side length of 13.9485/8.3745 Å (Figure c).

elements.content: The reactions of M(II) cation (M = Zn, Co, or Mn) with H2phda produce three complex pairs by the adjustment of two kinds of dipyridyl-type molecules. The structural differences show that both the auxiliary ligand and the metal center have great influences on the structure of the final assembly.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversities

The reactions of M(II) cation (M = Zn, Co, or Mn) with H2phda produce three complex pairs by the adjustment of two kinds of dipyridyl-type molecules. The structural differences show that both the auxiliary ligand and the metal center have great influences on the structure of the final assembly.

elements.content: On the one hand, it is shown that the secondary ligands have a significant effect on the construction of the frameworks; that is, the structural differences in each complex pairs are primarily affected by the introduction of N-donor ancillary ligands. For example, Zn(II) complexes display a single 66 - dia net with the superior cavities permitting the water-chain to be encapsulated when adding the bpa as auxiliary ligands and a 4-fold interpenetrated framework with no obvious cavities when dpe ligand is used, respectively. Similarly, cobalt complexes (3, 4) exhibit 2D (4,4) grids with mononuclear cobalt as node on the control of the bpa ligand and a 3D self-penetrated framework with (48668) rob topology in the light of binuclear Co as node on the adjustment of the dpe molecule, respectively. Manganese complex pairs (5, 6) display a (4,4) grid featuring 1D metal carboxylate units cross-linked by ancillary ligands; only the former, having a configuration similar to 3, contains linear carboxylate subunits built by mononuclear metal centers and the latter consist of ribbonlike carboxylate subunits built by dinuclear metal centers.

For example, Zn(II) complexes display a single 66 -  dia  net with the superior cavities permitting the water-chain to be encapsulated when adding the bpa as auxiliary ligands and a 4-fold interpenetrated framework with no obvious cavities when dpe ligand is used, respectively. Similarly, cobalt complexes (3, 4) exhibit 2D (4,4) grids with mononuclear cobalt as node on the control of the bpa ligand and a 3D self-penetrated framework with (48668)  rob  topology in the light of binuclear Co as node on the adjustment of the dpe molecule, respectively. Manganese complex pairs (5, 6) display a (4,4) grid featuring 1D metal carboxylate units cross-linked by ancillary ligands; only the former, having a configuration similar to 3, contains linear carboxylate subunits built by mononuclear metal centers and the latter consist of ribbonlike carboxylate subunits built by dinuclear metal centers.

elements.content: On the other hand, the metal center has a great effect on the structural assembly. All six complexes are categorized into two groups on the basis of used coligands: complexes 1, 3, 5 and complexes 2, 4, 6. Each group is prepared by following an almost uniform hydrothermal procedure and the identical linkers except using different metal centers. It is demonstrated that the nature of metal ions is an important factor in determining accessible coordination polymer structures. For example, the complexes 2, 4, 6 assembled in the same phda and dpe apply for structural diversities of MOFs. However, Zn(II) complex 2 features a 4-fold interpenetrated 66- dia framework, Co(II) complex 2 possesses a 3D self-penetrated network with (48668) rob topology, and yet Mn(II) complex 6 exhibits 2D layer containing phda-bridged binuclear manganese. The structural discrepancy can be attributed to various binding modes of organic linkers with different metal ions: the Zn(II) cation is inclined to a common four-coordinated geometry, and the Co(II) and Mn(II) cations are apt to six-coordinated even seven-coordinated coordination geometries.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stabilities of compound 1. TGA reveals that the removal of guest water molecules starts at room temperature and ends on heating to 110 °C (Figure a). The first weight loss of 10.94% corresponds to the loss of three lattice water molecules per formula unit (calcd: 10.9%). The dehydration process is followed by a plateau of stability from 110 to 205 °C, and then the framework rapidly collapses with a two-step weight loss until 850 °C. The observed final mass remnant of 15.01% likely representing deposition of ZnO agrees with the calculated value of 16.41%.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability of 1 

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stabilities of compound 1. TGA reveals that the removal of guest water molecules starts at room temperature and ends on heating to 110 °C (Figure a). The first weight loss of 10.94% corresponds to the loss of three lattice water molecules per formula unit (calcd: 10.9%). The dehydration process is followed by a plateau of stability from 110 to 205 °C, and then the framework rapidly collapses with a two-step weight loss until 850 °C. The observed final mass remnant of 15.01% likely representing deposition of ZnO agrees with the calculated value of 16.41%.

elements.content: TGA curve (a) and powder X-ray diffraction patterns (b) of complex 1.
elements.clean_text: 7  TGA curve (a) and powder X-ray diffraction patterns (b) of complex 1.

elements.content: In order to further prove the stability of polymeric framework in the removal of water molecules, complex 1 at a higher temperature 180 °C for 24 h is examined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), as shown in Figure b. The result shows the framework of 1 still has good crystallinity after removing lattice water guests, because all major peaks in experimental PXRD of the heated sample match quite well that of simulated and unheated samples, indicating the reasonable crystalline phase purity and higher thermal stabilities for this structure. However, the difference in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the microcrystalline powder samples. Furthermore, the accessible void in the desolvated structure of this compound is estimated to correspond to 16.7% of the total volume by calculating from single crystal structure with PLATON/SOLV. So, compound 1 exhibits permanent porosity in the absence of free solvent molecules, which may be potentially applied in some sorption fields.

elements.content: Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers are promising candidates for photoactive materials with potential applications. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of the free ligands and both zinc complexes 1 and 2 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties of 1 and 2 

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers are promising candidates for photoactive materials with potential applications. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of the free ligands and both zinc complexes 1 and 2 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Solid-state emission spectra for the powdered free H2phda ligand and zinc compounds 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 8  Solid-state emission spectra for the powdered free H2phda ligand and zinc compounds 1 and 2.

elements.content: The emission peak of free H2phda ligand is observed at about 353 nm and 371 nm resulting from the π–π* or n−π* transitions. On complexation of these ligands with the Zn(II) atom, the emission peaks occur at 359 and 376 nm for compound 1, and 358 and 372 nm for 2, respectively. Since the Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce due to their d10 configuration, the emissions of both compounds are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. They can probably be assigned to the intraligand charge transfer of H2phda ligand because a similar emission is observed for the free H2phda ligand and the dipyridyl-type coligands show almost no contribution to the emissions of the compounds due to their very weak fluorescent emission. In addition, the emissive slightly red-shifts relative to the free H2phda ligand may be considered to mainly originate from the coordination interactions between the metal atom and the ligand. Although more detailed theoretical and spectroscopic studies may be necessary for better understanding of the luminescent mechanism, the strong fluorescence emissions of those complexes make them potentially useful photoactive materials.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities for 4 and 6 were measured from 2 to 300 K in a 2000 Oe applied field, and shown as χm T and χm versus T plots in Figure . The χm T value at room temperature in 6 of 8.39 cm3 K mol–1 is close to that expected for a noninteracting pair of S = 5/2 ions (8.75 cm3 K mol–1, S = 5/2) of the Mn(II). However, the experimental χm T value of 4 at room temperature is 4.74 cm3 K mol–1, which is larger than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 expected for two magnetically uncoupled Co(II) ions (S = 3/2). This larger value is attributed to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χm T values decrease first slowly and then rapidly. This behavior suggests the existence of weak antiferromagnetic exchange behavior even if the single-ion effects, such as spin–orbit coupling, distortion from regular stereochemistry, electron delocalization, and crystal field mixing of excited states into the ground state, may also be present. The molar magnetic susceptibility over the full temperature range obeys the Curie–Weiss law giving Curie constant C = 4.93 cm3 K mol–1 and a negative Weiss constant θ = −10.01 K for 4 (Figure a), and Curie constant C = 8.51 cm3 K mol–1 and a negative Weiss constant θ = −2.52 K for 6 (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of 4 and 6 

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities for 4 and 6 were measured from 2 to 300 K in a 2000 Oe applied field, and shown as χm T and χm versus T plots in Figure . The χm T value at room temperature in 6 of 8.39 cm3 K mol-1 is close to that expected for a noninteracting pair of S = 5/2 ions (8.75 cm3 K mol-1, S = 5/2) of the Mn(II). However, the experimental χm T value of 4 at room temperature is 4.74 cm3 K mol-1, which is larger than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol-1 expected for two magnetically uncoupled Co(II) ions (S = 3/2). This larger value is attributed to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χm T values decrease first slowly and then rapidly. This behavior suggests the existence of weak antiferromagnetic exchange behavior even if the single-ion effects, such as spin-orbit coupling, distortion from regular stereochemistry, electron delocalization, and crystal field mixing of excited states into the ground state, may also be present. The molar magnetic susceptibility over the full temperature range obeys the Curie-Weiss law giving Curie constant C = 4.93 cm3 K mol-1 and a negative Weiss constant θ = -10.01 K for 4 (Figure a), and Curie constant C = 8.51 cm3 K mol-1 and a negative Weiss constant θ = -2.52 K for 6 (Figure b).

elements.content: In this contribution, we tried to understand the variables and strategies to control the network structure by the flexible dicarboxylate and dipyridyl-type linkers assembling into three well-defined complexes pairs. It is obviously shown that the ligands and the metal centers exert great influences on the structure of the final assembly. On the one hand, the coupled complexes reveal disparate structures regulated by bpa and dpe ancillary ligand, respectively, wherein the coupled zinc complexes feature the single dia net with superior cavities (1) and the 4-fold interpenetrated dia net with dense structure (2), the coupled cobalt complexes display the (4,4) grid (3) and the self-penetrated (48668) rob net (4), and two manganese complexes possess the (4,4) grids built by linear carboxylate subunits (5) and ribbonlike carboxylate subunits (6), respectively. On the other hand, all six complexes are categorized into two groups on the basis of used coligands, each of which contains different metal centers spaced by the identical linkers to bear various topology networks, which implies that the nature of metal cations can provoke a broad range of structure types. Although the detailed controlling factors for the synthesis of the complexes is elusive, the work illustrates that the flexible carboxylates are efficient linkers for the assembly of metal complexes with novel structures that can be efficiently regulated by N-donor ancillary ligands. Further investigations on this domain are underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this contribution, we tried to understand the variables and strategies to control the network structure by the flexible dicarboxylate and dipyridyl-type linkers assembling into three well-defined complexes pairs. It is obviously shown that the ligands and the metal centers exert great influences on the structure of the final assembly. On the one hand, the coupled complexes reveal disparate structures regulated by bpa and dpe ancillary ligand, respectively, wherein the coupled zinc complexes feature the single  dia  net with superior cavities (1) and the 4-fold interpenetrated  dia  net with dense structure (2), the coupled cobalt complexes display the (4,4) grid (3) and the self-penetrated (48668)  rob  net (4), and two manganese complexes possess the (4,4) grids built by linear carboxylate subunits (5) and ribbonlike carboxylate subunits (6), respectively. On the other hand, all six complexes are categorized into two groups on the basis of used coligands, each of which contains different metal centers spaced by the identical linkers to bear various topology networks, which implies that the nature of metal cations can provoke a broad range of structure types. Although the detailed controlling factors for the synthesis of the complexes is elusive, the work illustrates that the flexible carboxylates are efficient linkers for the assembly of metal complexes with novel structures that can be efficiently regulated by N-donor ancillary ligands. Further investigations on this domain are underway.

cln_elements.content:
Complex 1 displays a porous metal–organic framework with 66- dia topology. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) ion, one phda dianion, two one-half bpa molecules in special positions, and three guest water molecules. As shown in Figure a, the Zn(II) ion is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two symmetry-related bpa ligands (Zn(1)–N(1) = 2.042(5) and Zn(1)–N(2) = 2.059(5) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two symmetry-related phda anions (Zn(1)–O(3)#1 = 1.928(4) and Zn(1)–O(1) = 1.969(4) Å). Each phda anion through a bis(monodentate) coordinated mode bridges the adjacent Zn(II) atoms (Scheme a) to yield a undulating [Zn(phda)] n chain () with a through-ligand Zn···Zn contact distance of 8.9610 Å, which is further cross-linked by bpa coligands along two different directions to develop a 3D porous framework (Figure b). From a topological perspective, compound 1 can be described as a 4-connected net with 66 - dia topology (Figure c). Each metal center node is linked to four neighbors, forming six 6-membered circuits at each metal atom.

Thermal Stability of <bold>1</bold>

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stabilities of compound 1. TGA reveals that the removal of guest water molecules starts at room temperature and ends on heating to 110 °C (Figure a). The first weight loss of 10.94% corresponds to the loss of three lattice water molecules per formula unit (calcd: 10.9%). The dehydration process is followed by a plateau of stability from 110 to 205 °C, and then the framework rapidly collapses with a two-step weight loss until 850 °C. The observed final mass remnant of 15.01% likely representing deposition of ZnO agrees with the calculated value of 16.41%.

Magnetic Properties of <bold>4</bold> and <bold>6</bold>

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities for 4 and 6 were measured from 2 to 300 K in a 2000 Oe applied field, and shown as χm T and χm versus T plots in Figure . The χm T value at room temperature in 6 of 8.39 cm3 K mol–1 is close to that expected for a noninteracting pair of S = 5/2 ions (8.75 cm3 K mol–1, S = 5/2) of the Mn(II). However, the experimental χm T value of 4 at room temperature is 4.74 cm3 K mol–1, which is larger than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 expected for two magnetically uncoupled Co(II) ions (S = 3/2). This larger value is attributed to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χm T values decrease first slowly and then rapidly. This behavior suggests the existence of weak antiferromagnetic exchange behavior even if the single-ion effects, such as spin–orbit coupling, distortion from regular stereochemistry, electron delocalization, and crystal field mixing of excited states into the ground state, may also be present. The molar magnetic susceptibility over the full temperature range obeys the Curie–Weiss law giving Curie constant C = 4.93 cm3 K mol–1 and a negative Weiss constant θ = −10.01 K for 4 (Figure a), and Curie constant C = 8.51 cm3 K mol–1 and a negative Weiss constant θ = −2.52 K for 6 (Figure b).

cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination Modes of H2phda Observed in Complexes 1-6

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn(II) ion in 1. Symmetry codes: A = 1.5 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; B = 3 – x, 1 – y, –z; C = 3 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z. (b) A polyhedral view of the 3D open-porous structure. (c) Schematic representation of 66- dia topology for 1. (d) The 3D open framework filled by guest H2O molecules. (e) A water chain formed by H-bonding interactions.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn(II) ion in 1. Symmetry codes: A = 1.5 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; B = 3 - x, 1 - y, -z; C = 3 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z. (b) A polyhedral view of the 3D open-porous structure. (c) Schematic representation of 66- dia  topology for 1. (d) The 3D open framework filled by guest H2O molecules. (e) A water chain formed by H-bonding interactions.

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn(II) ions in 2. Symmetry codes: A = x, −1 + y, 1 + z; B = −1 + x, y, −1 + z; C = −1 + x, 1 + y, z. (b) View of 3D open-porous framework in 2. (c) The packing structure of 2 built by four interpenetrated 66- dia nets. (d) Topology view of 2 showing the interpenetrated details of four 66- dia net.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn(II) ions in 2. Symmetry codes: A = x, -1 + y, 1 + z; B = -1 + x, y, -1 + z; C = -1 + x, 1 + y, z. (b) View of 3D open-porous framework in 2. (c) The packing structure of 2 built by four interpenetrated 66- dia  nets. (d) Topology view of 2 showing the interpenetrated details of four 66- dia  net.

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Co(II) ions in 3. Symmetry codes: A = 1 + x, y, z; B = −1 + x, y, −1 + z. (b) View of a 2D layer structure. (c) The H-bonds in compound 3. (d) Side view of H-bonding bilayers.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) View of the coordination environment of Co(II) ions in 3. Symmetry codes: A = 1 + x, y, z; B = -1 + x, y, -1 + z. (b) View of a 2D layer structure. (c) The H-bonds in compound 3. (d) Side view of H-bonding bilayers.

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Co(II) ions in 4. Symmetry codes: A = 0.5 + x, −0.5 + y, z; B = 0.5 – x, −0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; C = 0.5 – x, 0.5 – y, 1 – z. (b) A carboxylate layer constructed by the phda anion-bridged Co dimers. (c) The 3D network featuring Co carboxylate layers pillared by dpe molecules. (d) Schematic representation of the 3D self-penetrating rob topology for 4.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) View of the coordination environment of Co(II) ions in 4. Symmetry codes: A = 0.5 + x, -0.5 + y, z; B = 0.5 - x, -0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; C = 0.5 - x, 0.5 - y, 1 - z. (b) A carboxylate layer constructed by the phda anion-bridged Co dimers. (c) The 3D network featuring Co carboxylate layers pillared by dpe molecules. (d) Schematic representation of the 3D self-penetrating  rob  topology for 4.

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Mn(II) ions in 5. Symmetry codes: A = 1 – x, y, 2.5 – z; B = –x, y, 0.5 – z; C = 1 – x, y, 1.5 – z; D = x, y, −1 + z. (b) View of the 2D layer structure.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) View of the coordination environment of Mn(II) ions in 5. Symmetry codes: A = 1 - x, y, 2.5 - z; B = -x, y, 0.5 - z; C = 1 - x, y, 1.5 - z; D = x, y, -1 + z. (b) View of the 2D layer structure.

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the coordination environment of Mn(II) ions in 6. Symmetry codes: A = –x, 2 – y, 2 – z; B = 1 + x, −1 + y, z; C = 2 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z. (b) View of 1D ribbonlike chain. (c) The 2D layer featuring Mn carboxylate chains pillared by dpe molecules. (d) A space-filling view stacked by adjacent 2D layers.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) View of the coordination environment of Mn(II) ions in 6. Symmetry codes: A = -x, 2 - y, 2 - z; B = 1 + x, -1 + y, z; C = 2 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z. (b) View of 1D ribbonlike chain. (c) The 2D layer featuring Mn carboxylate chains pillared by dpe molecules. (d) A space-filling view stacked by adjacent 2D layers.
